sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: The countdown to liftoff is upon us. The highly anticipated launch of NASA's giant new James Webb Space Telescope on Saturday

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: promises to look deeper into the universe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: Scientists are hoping its state-of-the-art capabilities will allow them to study the atmospheres of distant planets.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: They're also hoping for signs of life to be detected.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: For more on this, I'm now joined by Dr. Francisco Diego, who is an astronomer at the University College London.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: Thank you for joining us, Dr. Diego.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_04
sentences.sentence: This launch has faced many obstacles.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: Can you talk us through what we can expect when it does take off?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: This telescope, both from the technology that is behind it, the design, the materials, everything, plus the kind of work that it's going to do in the next few years is amazing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: It's completely astonishing.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: So a lot of nations involved, a lot of scientists involved, giving the most of their careers in this adventure. Now to see them put in a top of a rocket and then go into space to a very distant place just behind the moon.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Very, very impressive.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_16
sentences.sentence: How can it give us a better understanding of our universe and our space in it?

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: Observing in the middle infrared, the James Webb is going to be able to observe the formation, the very first stars in the universe.

sentences.speaker: SPEAKER_07
sentences.sentence: We're talking more than 13,000 million years ago, 30,000 million years ago, just after the formation of the universe, when the first stars emerged, the formation of galaxies in the cosmological part of the science that is going to do, plus the formation of stars in general in our Milky Way galaxy, the formation of planets, the formation of solar systems, which is extremely important, and also the characterization of the conditions of the planets that we already know, alien planets around the nearby stars characterize their atmospheres, characterize their composition. And the James Webb is going to have a perfect opportunity to do this.
